page.title: Battle of Berne (1954 FIFA World Cup)

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{About|1954 FIFA World Cup match|French defeat of Swiss forces 5 March 1798|Battle of Berne (1798)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox football match | title = 1954 FIFA World Cup Quarter-final | image = | event = | team1 = [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] | team1association = {{flagicon|HUN|1949|size=30px}} | team1score = 4 | team2 = [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] | team2association = {{flagicon|BRA|size=30px}} | team2score = 2 | details = | date = 27 June 1954 | stadium = [[Wankdorf Stadium]] | city = [[Berne]] | referee = [[Arthur Edward Ellis|Arthur Ellis]] ([[The Football Association|England]]) | attendance = 40,000 | weather = }} '''The Battle of Berne''' is used to refer to a [[association football|football]] match at the [[FIFA World Cup 1954|1954 World Cup]] between [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], a quarter-final played on 27 June 1954 at the [[Wankdorf Stadium]] in [[Berne]], [[Switzerland]]. Violent conduct and fighting prompted English referee [[Arthur Edward Ellis|Arthur Ellis]] to send off three players during the match. Fighting between the teams continued in the dressing rooms after the final whistle. ==Background== Brazil had scored six goals in two group games, and Hungary had scored 17. Brazil had a reputation for attractive and attacking football; in their group games, they beat Mexico 5–0, and drew the other 1–1 with Yugoslavia after extra time. Yugoslavia had beaten France 1–0 in their other group game, which meant that both Brazil and Yugoslavia were equal on points in their group. Goal difference was not used to decide who finished top of the group; instead, lots were drawn, with Brazil being elected group winners. Hungary had revolutionized football tactics and coaching in Europe. Their fluid and open style of play – an early form of [[Total Football|total football]] – meant that they were unbeaten for the previous 4 years. Hungary were clear winners of their group, winning both of their group games – they beat South Korea 9–0, and West Germany 8–3. ==The match== The match was played in driving rain, producing slippery conditions and a hard to control ball. Hungary took the lead in the third minute, with [[Nándor Hidegkuti]] scoring. Four minutes later, [[Sándor Kocsis]] made it 2–0 to Hungary. Brazil was awarded a penalty; [[Djalma Santos]] scored to make it 2–1 at half time. In the second half, Hungary was awarded a penalty; [[Mihály Lantos]] scored to make the score 3–1. The penalty award was the cue for a pitch invasion by Brazilian journalists and officials, who had to be ushered off by police. The game then degenerated into a series of increasingly violent fouls and cynical tactics, with Brazilian forward [[Júlio Botelho|Julinho]] somehow scoring to bring the score to 3–2. After this, [[József Bozsik]] was fouled by [[Nilton Santos]]; the two men started fighting, and both were sent off. Hungary scored a fourth goal via [[Sándor Kocsis]] to make the score 4–2 to Hungary. The last moments of the game was little more than a running battle between the two teams; Brazilian forward [[Humberto Tozzi]] kicked Hungary's [[Gyula Lorant]] prior to the final whistle and was sent off. In total, 42 free kicks and 2 penalties were awarded, with 4 cautions and 3 dismissals issued.{{cite web |url=http://www.scoreshelf.com/dqcc/en/World_Cup/1954/HUN_v_BRA |title=Hungary vs Brazil: World CUP 1954 Quarter Final |publisher=ScoreShelf.com |accessdate=11 October 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709114635/http://scoreshelf.com/dqcc/en/World_Cup/1954/HUN_v_BRA |archive-date=9 July 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The ill-temper continued after the game, with the Brazilian players invading the Hungarian dressing room and continuing the on-pitch fighting. Despite evidence from independent witnesses of violent conduct from both sides, football's governing body [[FIFA]] did nothing, leaving discipline to the respective countries.{{citation needed|date=March 2012}} ==Post-match commentary== The game's referee [[Arthur Edward Ellis|Arthur Ellis]] commented: "I thought it was going to be the greatest game I'd ever see. I was on top of the world. Whether politics and religion had something to do with it I don't know, but they behaved like animals. It was a disgrace. It was a horrible match. In today's climate so many players would have been sent off the game would have been abandoned. My only thought was that I was determined to finish it."{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-ellis-a-knockout-during-the-battle-of-berne-1163887.html |title=Football: Ellis a knockout during the Battle of Berne – Sport |publisher=The Independent |date=9 June 1998 |accessdate=12 February 2011}} ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper correspondent on 28 June 1954 drew a similar conclusion; "Never in my life have I seen such cruel tackling, the cutting down of opponents as if with a scythe, followed by threatening attitudes and sly jabs when officialdom was engaged elsewhere."{{cite web |url=http://teora.hit.no/dspace/bitstream/2282/954/1/Brawling_in_Berne.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718171937/http://teora.hit.no/dspace/bitstream/2282/954/1/Brawling_in_Berne.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 July 2011 |title=Gerd von der Lippe |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=12 February 2011 }} "This was a battle; a brutal, savage match," recalled Hungary manager [[Gustav Sebes]], who needed four stitches for a facial wound received during the fighting. "At the end we had won 4–2 but it wasn't over yet. Brazilian photographers and fans flooded on to the pitch and police were called to clear it. Players clashed in the tunnel and a small war broke out in the corridor to the dressing rooms - everyone was having a go; fans, players and officials."{{cite web|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2006-05-03-brazil-swap-beauty-for-brutality-in-battle-of-berne |title=Brazil swap beauty for brutality in 'Battle of Berne' – Sport – Mail & Guardian Online |publisher=Mg.co.za |date=3 May 2006 |accessdate=12 February 2011}} ==The Battle of Berne's status in International Football's highest rated matches== The "''Battle of Berne''" in theoretical abstract terms, was one of the highest ranked contests of the 20th century according to the [[World Football Elo Ratings|Elo rating system]] in men's senior international competition. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%;" |- !Rank!!Combined

{{Use American English|date=October 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox award | name = Best Outdoor Sportsman ESPY Award | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = best outdoor sportsperson | presenter = ESPN | country = | location = Los Angeles (2008) | year = 2002 | year2 = 2008 | holder = [[Scott Smiley]] (USA) | website = {{URL|http://www.espn.co.uk/espys/}} }} The '''Best Outdoor Sportsman ESPY Award''' was an annual award honoring the achievements of an athlete from the world of outdoor sports —understood as those related to [[Wilderness|outdoor]] [[recreation]] and [[nature]]-based occupation, including [[Recreational fishing|sport fishing]], most especially of [[Bass fishing|bass]], and [[Lumberjack#Loggersports|lumberjacking]], most especially the [[Logrolling (sport)|logrolling]], [[Woodchopping|wood chopping]], and high-climbing disciplines thereof—on an [[Amateur sports|amateur]] or [[Professional sports|professional]] level primarily in the United States or Canada.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tfTXAQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=American+Sports:+A+History+of+Icons,+Idols+and+Ideas&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1jbbW4-3YAhWkK8AKHWosCrIQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=ESPY&f=false|title=American Sports: A History of Icons, Idols and Ideas|last=R. Nelson|first=Murry|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2013|isbn=0-313-39753-8|location=[[Santa Barbara, California]]|pages=399–401|accessdate=June 24, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123190837/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tfTXAQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=American+Sports:+A+History+of+Icons,+Idols+and+Ideas&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1jbbW4-3YAhWkK8AKHWosCrIQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=ESPY&f=false|archivedate=January 23, 2018|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}} It was first presented as part of the [[ESPY Award|ESPY Awards]] at the 2002 edition after broadcaster [[ESPN]] purchased the [[Bass Anglers Sportsman Society]] in the summer of 2001. The Best Outdoor Sportsman ESPY Award trophy, designed by sculptor [[Lawrence Nowlan]],{{cite news|url=http://www.timesargus.com/article/20130802/NEWS03/708029923/0/FEATURES10|title=Sculptor commissioned to complete Joe Frazier statue has died|last=Avard|first=Christian|date=August 2, 2013|work=[[Barre Montpelier Times Argus]]|access-date=January 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221231935/http://www.timesargus.com/article/20130802/NEWS03/708029923/0/FEATURES10|archive-date=February 21, 2014|dead-url=yes}} was given to the outdoor sportsperson adjudged to be the best in a given [[calendar year]]. From the 2004 to 2008 ceremonies, the winner was chosen by online voting through choices selected by the ESPN Select Nominating Committee.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espy2004/s/2004/0421/1786981.html|title=The 2004 ESPY Awards - Fans to decide all 2004 ESPY Award winners|publisher=[[ESPN]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123190648/http://www.espn.com/espy2004/s/2004/0421/1786981.html|archive-date=January 23, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=January 23, 2018|df=mdy-all}} Before that, determination of the winners was made by an panel of experts.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espy/features/01083044.html|title=Committee is newly found|date=February 3, 1999|publisher=ESPN|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123190739/http://www.espn.com/espy/features/01083044.html|archive-date=January 23, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=23 January 2018|df=mdy-all}} Through the [[2001 in sports|2001]] iteration of the ESPY Awards, ceremonies were conducted in February of each year to honor achievements over the previous calendar year; awards presented thereafter are conferred in July and reflect performance from the June previous.{{efn|Because of the [[ESPY Awards#Timing|rescheduling]] of the ESPY Awards ceremony, the award presented in 2002 was given in consideration of performance betwixt February 2001 and June 2002.}}{{cite press release|title=New categories unveiled for The 2002 ESPY Awards|date=2002|publisher=ESPN|url=http://www.espn.com/espy2002/s/awardcategories.html|access-date=December 20, 2017|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222052554/http://www.espn.com/espy2002/s/awardcategories.html|archive-date=December 22, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The inaugural winner of the Best Outdoor Sportsman ESPY Award in 2002 was American [[Bass fishing|bass angler]] [[Kevin VanDam]]. During 2001 and 2002, he won the [[Bassmaster Classic XXXI]], the 2001 Wal-Mart FLW Championship, and attained the rank of the top-ranked angler worldwide during that period.{{Cite web|url=http://bassfan.com/news_article/370/vandam-wins-first-outdoor-espy-award#.W7uDCntKjIU|title=VanDam Wins First Outdoor ESPY Award|date=July 11, 2002|publisher=BassFan|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008171945/http://bassfan.com/news_article/370/vandam-wins-first-outdoor-espy-award|archive-date=October 8, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=October 8, 2018}} VanDam became the first of two bass anglers to be nominated, and hence to win, an ESPY Award. Bass anglers have been the most successful sportspeople (with two victories and eight nominations) with the win of Jay Yelas at the 2003 iteration. It was presented to one woman in its history, [[Logrolling (sport)|logroller]] [[Tina Bosworth]], in the 2004 edition. The winner of the Best Outdoor Sportsman ESPY Award in 2005 was [[Lumberjack|lumberjacker]] [[J. R. Salzman]] after winning 14 medals at the [[Great Outdoor Games]] and claimed five logrolling titles at the [[Lumberjack World Championship]] between 1998 and 2005. After that, the accolade was partially replaced by the [[Best Angler ESPY Award]] for the 2006 edition before returning the next year. It was permanently discontinued after the 2008 ceremony.{{Cite web|url=http://ultimatebass.com/fishing/bass-fishing-news/bass-fishing-industry-news/tammy-richardson-wins-espy/|title=Tammy Richardson Wins ESPY|date=July 19, 2006|publisher=Ultimate Bass|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008171944/http://ultimatebass.com/fishing/bass-fishing-news/bass-fishing-industry-news/tammy-richardson-wins-espy/|archive-date=October 8, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=October 8, 2018}} ==List of winners and nominees== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope=col |Year ! scope=col class=unsortable| Image ! scope=col | Athlete ! scope=col | Nationality ! scope=col | Sport ! scope=col class=unsortable | Nominees ! scope=col class=unsortable | Refs |- | [[2002 ESPY Awards|2002]] | [[File:USMC-100421-M-3392W-032 (Kevin VanDam - Crop).jpg|100px|alt=Kevin VanDam in 2012]] ! scope=row | {{sort name|Kevin|VanDam}} | {{flag|USA}} | [[Bass fishing|Bass angling]] | align=left | [[Rick Clunn]] ({{flag|USA}}) – [[Bass fishing|Bass angling]]

[[Skip Storch]] ({{flag|USA}}) – [[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]] | {{cite web|url=https://www.backpacker.com/news-and-events/blind-iraq-vet-wins-outdoor-espy|title=Blind Iraq Vet Wins Outdoor ESPY|last=Herrel|first=Katie|date=July 22, 2008|website=[[Backpacker (magazine)|Backpacker]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008195229/https://www.backpacker.com/news-and-events/blind-iraq-vet-wins-outdoor-espy|archive-date=October 8, 2018|deadurl=no|accessdate=October 8, 2018}}{{cite news|last=Thomson|first=Gus|title=Media Life:ESPY nomination for Auburn’s Bassmaster champ Skeet Reese|url=http://www.auburnjournal.com/article/media-lifeespy-nomination-auburn’s-bassmaster-champ-skeet-reese|newspaper=[[Auburn Journal]]|date=July 3, 2008|accessdate=October 8, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105235226/http://www.auburnjournal.com/article/media-lifeespy-nomination-auburn%E2%80%99s-bassmaster-champ-skeet-reese|archivedate=January 5, 2018|deadurl=no}} |- |} ==See also== * [[Bassmaster Classic]] * [[Great Outdoor Games]] * [[Lumberjack World Championships]] * [[Sport fishing]] ==Notes and references== === Notes === {{notes}} === References === {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.espn.com.au/espys/}} {{ESPYs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Best Outdoor Sportsman Espy Award}} [[Category:ESPY Awards]] [[Category:Outdoor recreation]] [[Category:Awards established in 2002]] [[Category:Awards disestablished in 2005]] [[Category:2002 establishments in the United States]]

revision.text:
[[Image:bike-rollers.jpg|right|thumb]] [[File:Antique bicycle on antique rollers in US Bicycling Hall of Fame.jpg|right|thumb|antique rollers in [[United States Bicycling Hall of Fame]]]] '''Bicycle rollers''' are a type of [[bicycle trainer]] that make it possible to ride a bicycle indoors without moving forward. However, unlike other types of bicycle trainers, rollers do not attach to the bicycle frame, and the rider must balance him or herself on the rollers while training. Bicycle rollers normally consist of three cylinders, drums, or "rollers" (two for the rear wheel and one for the front), on top of which the bicycle rides. A [[Belt (mechanical)|belt]] connects the middle roller to the front roller, causing the front wheel of the bicycle to spin when the bicycle is pedaled. The spacing of bicycle rollers can usually be adjusted to match the bicycle's [[Bicycle and motorcycle geometry#Wheelbase|wheelbase]]. Generally, the front roller is adjusted to be slightly ahead of the hub of the front wheel.
== History == Bicycle rollers are nearly as old as the bicycle itself. [[Charles Minthorn Murphy|Mile-a-minute Murphy]] is pictured riding on them as early as 1901.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.goldsprint.com/2010/09/10/mile-a-minute-murphy/ |title = Mile a Minute Murphy roller racing against Tom Butler |publisher = Goldsprint.com Roller Racing and Goldsprint |accessdate = 2011-07-28 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110512100430/http://www.goldsprint.com/2010/09/10/mile-a-minute-murphy/ |archive-date = 2011-05-12 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
== Riding on rollers == Balancing the bicycle without riding off the rollers is an extra challenge for the rider and requires much more balance and attention than [[bicycle trainer]]s. Some cyclists find that this increased attention to balance enhances their workout, while other cyclists simply prefer the more stable trainers. Rollers are also used by bicycle racers to finely tune their balance, a skill needed for [[Drafting (aerodynamics)|drafting]] and the close quarters of a [[peloton]] during races. {{Citation needed|date=March 2012}}
Novice cyclists often start by placing the bicycle rollers in a hallway or door frame where there is a nearby wall for support in the case of a fall. Removing any sharp and dangerous objects from the area is a must and a helmet is often worn, even though the user might be indoors. Beginners quickly discover that it is easier to maintain one's balance by focusing on a point a few yards ahead rather than looking directly down at the front wheel. In addition, it is easier to stay on the rollers in a higher gear when the wheels are spinning faster. Also, the user has no forward [[momentum]] while on bicycle rollers, which drastically reduces the possibility of injury in the event of a loss of balance or a fall.[[Newton's laws of motion#Newton's second law]]
==Construction==
===Rollers=== The rollers themselves may be made from [[wood]],<ref name="BikeWorks">,{{cite web | url = http://www.bikecult.com/works/rollers.html | title = Bike Works NYC Bicycle Roller Racing Machine | accessdate = 2006-12-19| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070108091753/http://www.bikecult.com/works/rollers.html| archivedate= 8 January 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[aluminum alloy]],<ref name="Travel Tac Technique Pro Alloy Rollers">{{cite web | url = http://www.performancebike.com/bikes/Product_10052_10551_1028745_-1_1501503_20000_1501509 | title = Performance Bicycle Travel Tac Technique Pro Alloy Rollers | accessdate = 2010-03-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100306021123/http://www.performancebike.com/bikes/Product_10052_10551_1028745_-1_1501503_20000_1501509| archivedate= 6 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> or [[plastic]].<ref name="Elite Parabolic Rollers">{{cite web | url = http://www.roadbikereview.com/cat/training/trainers/elite/PRD_331252_1663crx.aspx | title = Elite Parabolic Rollers | accessdate = 10/9/2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071008222333/http://www.roadbikereview.com/cat/training/trainers/elite/PRD_331252_1663crx.aspx| archivedate= 8 October 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Aluminum alloy is usually a better choice because plastic rollers tend to bend and misshape from their regular cylindrical shape after use. Some rollers also have a concave cylinder shape (parabolic) to help keep the rider in the center of the rollers.<ref name="BikeWorks"/><ref name="Elite Parabolic Rollers"/><ref name="Nashbar Parabolic">{{cite web | url = http://www.nashbar.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/ProductPopupView?catalogId=10052&storeId=10053&productId=173072&langId=-1&parent_category_rn=201561&top_category=10000 | title = Nashbar Aluminum Reduced Radius Rollers | accessdate = 2010-02-27}}</ref>
===Frame=== The frame may be made from welded steel or extruded aluminum. The frame may fold in the middle for storage or transport.<ref name="BikeWorks"/>
==Variations== [[File:Indoor trainer.JPG|thumb|A flexible roller system allowing longitudinal movement.]] Rollers are available in different widths (from 10" to 18") and diameters (from 4.5" to 2.25" for higher resistance).<ref name="KreitlerRollers">{{cite web |url=http://www.kreitler.com/product.php?section=product&item=which_model |title=Kreitler Roller |accessdate=2006-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107100811/http://www.kreitler.com/product.php?section=product&item=which_model |archivedate=2008-01-07 |df= }}</ref> Some bicycle rollers use two front drums or cylinders instead of just one.
Resistance may be added by having the spinning rollers driving some additional mechanism such as a fan.<ref name="KreitlerAccessories">{{cite web |url=http://www.kreitler.com/product.php?section=product&item=accessories |title=Kreitler Roller Accessories |accessdate=2006-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107100730/http://www.kreitler.com/product.php?section=product&item=accessories |archivedate=2008-01-07 |df= }}</ref> Some rollers have an internal flywheel on the back cylinder. This mimics real-world resistance to continuous acceleration and makes it possible to coast for up to 30 seconds.<ref name="TruTrainer">{{cite web | url = http://www.trutrainer.com/products_rollers.shtml | title = TruTrainer - Premium Bicycle Rollers | accessdate = 2008-02-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080307224338/http://www.trutrainer.com/products_rollers.shtml| archivedate= 7 March 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
It is possible to remove the front wheel and mount the front fork in a stand (usually sold separately) to duplicate the stability of other [[bicycle trainer]]s.
Some rollers place the roller frame inside an external track so they can move (slide) fore and aft - which allow for simulating extreme pedalling off the saddle, as if climbing a hill. Strong elastic bands or springs are attached to each corner of the frame and pull and hold the roller frame in the tracks. A bicycle on the road can move fore and aft relative to the rider, and these rollers attempt to duplicate this effect.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.insideride.com/index.php?option=com_frontpage&Itemid=1| title= E-Motion Rollers| accessdate= 2009-12-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091030235956/http://www.insideride.com/index.php?option=com_frontpage&Itemid=1| archivedate= 2009-10-30| deadurl= yes| df= }}</ref>
==Roller racing==
Rollers may also be used for roller races (or [[goldsprint]]s if fork stands are used). Two or more bikes are placed on rollers side by side, the rollers are connected to a timing system. Timing systems either use modern electronics and digital projection, or a large analog clock with a hand for every rider representing their distance traveled. Roller racing was popular in 1950s [[United Kingdom|Britain]], often preceding films at the cinema or taking place in between dances at dance halls.<ref name="Rolling the Night Away">{{cite web |url=http://www.rapha.cc/index.php?page=122 |title=Rolling the Night Away. Therese Bjorn |accessdate=2007-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070107174909/http://www.rapha.cc/index.php?page=122 |archivedate=2007-01-07 |df= }}</ref> <!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:RollerRace.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Roller Race - Shoreditch Townhall (Ben Brown)|{{Deletable image-caption|1=Thursday, 8 May 2008|date=March 2012}}]] -->The [http://britishschoolscyclingassociation.com British Schools Cycling Association] carries on the tradition of true roller racing without fork stands and maintains the BSCA National Competition Roller Records<ref name="British Schools Cycling Association">{{cite web |url=http://www.bsca.org.uk/newwebsite/Records/Records/rollrecs.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121224001712/http://www.bsca.org.uk/newwebsite/Records/Records/rollrecs.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-12-24 |title=British Schools Cycling Association |accessdate=2012-07-02 }}</ref>
In 1993, the [[Century Road Club Association]] of [[New York City]] retired their vintage rollers and mechanical dial for Kreitler Rollers and a computer system that could clock up to six racers at a time.<ref name="Century Road Club Association January 2003">{{cite web |url = http://www.crca.net/newsletters/2003january.pdf |title = Century Road Club Association January 2003 |accessdate = 2012-07-02 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070203160241/http://www.crca.net/newsletters/2003january.pdf |archive-date = 2007-02-03 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> Elsewhere in America, every winter a [[USA Cycling]] sanctioned event called the Iowa Roller Race Series defines roller racing champions.<ref name="Bike World Iowa">{{cite web | url = http://bikeworldiowa.com/page.cfm?PageID=472 | title = Bike World Iowa | accessdate = 2012-07-02}}</ref><ref name="Iowa Roller Race Series Information">{{cite web |url=http://thefullsked.cloudaccess.net/featured-events/82-iowa-roller-race-series-information.html |title=Iowa Roller Race Series Information |accessdate=2012-07-02 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The series uses Kreitler Rollers and a DOS program Roller Fusion, which was commissioned in the 1990s by the late Al Kreitler. In honor of Al Kreitler, the promoter of the Iowa Roller Race Series, Greg Harper, organized the 2011 Al Kreitler Memorial Killer 2-Mile Roller Races.<ref name="2011 Al Kreitler Memorial Killer 2-Mile Roller Races">{{cite web |url=http://www.bickelsinc.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/2011-Al-Kreitler-Memorial-Killer-2.pdf |title=2011 Al Kreitler Memorial Killer 2-Mile Roller Races |accessdate=2012-07-02 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> (To clarify, Al Kreitler was not killed; his dog was named "Killer.")<ref name="About Kreitler">{{cite web |url=http://www.mountainracingproducts.com/kreitler/about-kreitler/ |title=About Kreitler |accessdate=2012-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805010934/http://www.mountainracingproducts.com/kreitler/about-kreitler/ |archivedate=2012-08-05 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Bicycle tire#Indoor use|Bicycle tires for indoor use]] * [[Bicycle trainer]] * [[Exercise bicycle]] * [[Outline of cycling]] * [[Goldsprint]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20161011124652/http://www.opensprints.com/ OpenSprints] - [[Open Source]] hardware and software for Roller Racing *[https://web.archive.org/web/20161005143652/http://www.rollapaluza.com/ Rollapaluza] - Roller Racing in:[[London]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081026161445/http://www.thisiswonky.com/news.php?item=46 WONKY] - Roller Racing Videos in:[[London]] * [[www.koersoprollen.com|Koers op Rollen:]] Roller Racing in Flanders, Belgium and the Netherlands * British Schools Cycling Association - [https://britishschoolscyclingassociation.com/] [https://britishschoolscyclingassociation.com/ www.britishschoolscyclingassociation.com]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2018}} In [[Modern history of East Asian martial arts|East Asian martial arts]], the '''black belt''' denotes a high competence in the martial art. It is often associated with a teaching grade though frequently not the highest grade or the "expert" of public perception.<ref>{{Cite news|title= Myths and Misconceptions Part 1 - Vol 44 No. 1|work= Black Belt Magazine|date= |url= http://www.judo-chikara.nl/2014/06/myths-and-misconceptions-part-1-vol-44.html|accessdate= 2010-01-29|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140606221959/http://www.judo-chikara.nl/2014/06/myths-and-misconceptions-part-1-vol-44.html|archivedate= 2014-06-06|df= }}</ref> It is a relatively recent invention (dating from the late 19th century).<ref name=judorank>{{Cite web | last =Ohlenkamp | first =Neil | title =The Judo Rank System | publisher =JudoInfo.com | date = March 25, 2007 | url = http://www.judoinfo.com/obi.htm | accessdate = 2007-10-15 }} </ref>
==Origin== The systematic use of belt color to denote the rank was first used in Japan by [[Jigoro Kano]], the founder of [[judo]], who first devised the colored belt system using [[obi (martial arts)|obi]] (sash), and awarded the first black belts to denote a [[Dan rank]] in the 1880s. Previously, Japanese [[Koryu]] instructors tended to provide certificates.<ref>Fumon, Tanaka; ''Samurai fighting arts: the spirit and the practice'', Kodansha International, 2003 {{ISBN|9784770028983}} p25</ref> Initially the wide obi was used; as practitioners trained in [[kimono]], only [[white belt|white]] and black obi were used. It was not until the early 1900s, after the introduction of the [[judogi]], that an expanded colored belt system of awarding rank was created.<ref name=judorank/> Other martial arts later adopted the custom or a variation of it (e.g., using colored sashes) to denote rank. This includes martial arts that traditionally did not have a formalized rank structure. This kind of ranking is less common in arts that do not claim a far eastern origin, though it is used in the [[Marine Corps Martial Arts Program]].
==Relative rank== [[File:PRehse002-cropped.jpg|thumb|left|Two [[aikido]] black belts training]] Rank and belts are not equivalent between arts, styles, or even within some organizations<ref>{{cite web|title=Karate Belt Ranks — History and Present|url=https://www.fullpotentialma.com/karate-belt-ranks-history-and-present/|publisher=Full Potential Martial Arts, San Diego}}</ref>. In some arts, a black belt is expected in three years, while in others ten years may be common. Testing for black belt is commonly more rigorous and more centralized than for lower grades.
==Ability== In contrast to the "black belt as master" stereotype, a black belt commonly indicates the wearer is competent in a style's basic technique and principles.<ref name=judorank/> Since in many styles a black belt takes approximately three to six years of training to achieve, a possible analogy might be a [[bachelor's degree]]: the student has a good understanding of fundamental concepts and ability, but has not yet perfected their skills. In this analogy a [[graduate degree]] would represent advancement past the first degree. [[Brazilian jiu-jitsu]] would be a notable exception to this, as a black belt for a jiu-jitsu practitioner typically takes 7–12 years of training to earn, and a black belt holder is generally viewed as an expert in the art.
Another way to describe this links to the terms used in Japanese arts; [[shodan (rank)|shodan]] (for a first degree black belt), means literally the first/beginning step, and the next grades, nidan and sandan are each numbered as "ni" is two and "san" is three, meaning second step, third step, etc. The [[Shodan (rank)|shodan]] black belt is not the end of training but rather as a beginning to advanced learning: the individual now "knows how to walk" and may thus begin the "journey".
As a "black belt" is commonly viewed as conferring some status, achieving one has been used as a marketing "gimmick", for example a guarantee of being awarded one within a specific period or if a specific amount is paid.<ref name=MichaelJai>{{Cite news|title=Michael Jai White Ignites Black Dynamite |work=Black Belt Magazine |date= |url=http://www.blackbeltmag.com/michael_jai_white_black_dynamite/archives/816 |accessdate=2009-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102132306/http://blackbeltmag.com/michael_jai_white_black_dynamite/archives/816 |archivedate=2010-01-02 |df= }}</ref> Some schools place profit ahead of ability when using these tactics and are sometimes referred to as [[McDojo]]s or belt factories.<ref name=McDojo>Cotroneo, Christian. (November 26, 2006) [[Toronto Star]]. There are also associations that give higher vlack belt grades for a fee for people who join them. The degree is often awarded by people with no competence in the art. That is the reason for many western martial arts teachers who have several 8,9 or 10 degree black belts
.''[https://www.thestar.com/article/154329 Kicking it up at the McDojo.]'' Section: News; Page A12. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016173119/http://www.thestar.com/article/154329 |date=October 16, 2007 }}</ref>
===Teaching=== In some Japanese schools, after obtaining a black belt the student also begins to instruct, and may be referred to as a [[senpai]] (senior student) or [[sensei]] (teacher). In others, a black belt student should not be called sensei until they are sandan (third degree black belt), or the titles kyosa or sabom in [[Korean martial arts]] as second degree or higher, as this denotes a greater degree of experience and a sensei must have this and grasp of what is involved in teaching a martial art.
==Higher grades== [[File:Rhee TKD Black Belts.jpg|thumb|right|Some martial art schools use embroidered bars to denote different levels of [[Dan rank|black belt rank]], as shown on these [[taekwondo]] 1st, 2nd, and 3rd ''dan'' black belts.]]
In [[Japanese martial arts]] the further subdivisions of black belt ranks may be linked to ''[[dan (rank)#Usage in martial arts|dan]]'' grades and indicated by 'stripes' on the belt. Yūdansha (roughly translating from Japanese to "person who holds a ''dan'' grade") is often used to describe those who hold a black belt rank. While the belt remains black, stripes or other insignia may be added to denote seniority, in some arts, very senior grades will wear differently colored belts. In judo and some forms of [[karate]], a sixth dan will wear a red and white belt. The red and white belt is often reserved only for ceremonial occasions, and a regular black belt is still worn during training. At 9th or 10th dan some schools award [[Red belt (martial arts)|red]]. In some schools of [[Jujutsu]], the [[Shihan]] rank and higher wear purple belts. These other colors are often still referred to collectively as "black belts".<ref name=MichaelJai/><ref name=BecomingaBB>{{Cite news|title=Becoming A Black Belt|work=Fight Magazine|date=|url=http://www.fightmagazine.com/mma-magazine/mma-article.asp?aid=298&issid=22|accessdate=2010-01-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711002412/http://www.fightmagazine.com/mma-magazine/mma-article.asp?aid=298&issid=22|archivedate=2011-07-11|df=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Brazilian jiu-jitsu ranking system]] * [[Kyū]] * [[Rank in Judo]] {{clear}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070221081754/http://www.judoinfo.com/karateranks.htm Origins of the Karate Rank System]

[[Western Stima F.C.|Western Stima]] | seating_capacity = 5,000https://int.soccerway.com/teams/kenya/homeboyz-fc/23717/venue/ }} The '''Bukhungu Stadium''' is a multi-purpose [[stadium]] in [[Kakamega]], [[Kenya]]. It used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Western Stima]] of the [[Kenyan Premier League]]. The stadium holds 5,000 spectators. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/kenya.shtml Stadium information] *{{coord|0|17|22|N|34|45|37|E}} {{Sports venues in Kenya}} [[Category:Football venues in Kenya]] [[Category:Sport in Western Province (Kenya)]] {{Kenya-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox Minor League Baseball | name = Dominican Summer League Red Sox | founded = 1997 | city = | misc = |class level = Rookie |past class level= |current league = [[Dominican Summer League]] |conference = |division = Northwest (DSL Red Sox 1)
North (DSL Red Sox 2) |past league = |majorleague = [[Boston Red Sox]] |pastmajorleague = |nickname = Red Sox |pastnames = |ballpark = El Toro Complex
carr. Mella KM 23.5, El Toro, DR |pastparks = |leaguenum = 1 |leaguechamps = 2016 |divnum = |divisionchamps = |owner = Boston Red Sox |manager = [[Aly González]] (DSL Red Sox 1)
[[Fernando Tatís]] (DSL Red Sox 2) |gm = [[José Zapata]] (field coordinator) }} The '''Dominican Summer League Red Sox''', often called the '''DSL Red Sox''', are a [[Minor League Baseball]] affiliate of the [[Boston Red Sox]] of [[Major League Baseball]], playing in the foreign [[Dominican Summer League]]. The team, classed as a [[Rookie League]] franchise, plays at the El Toro Complex in the [[Dominican Republic]]. As of the [[2018 Boston Red Sox season]], the field coordinator is [[José Zapata]], and the Red Sox are fielding two teams; one managed by [[Fernando Tatís]] and the other managed by [[Aly González]].{{cite news |url=https://www.mlb.com/news/red-sox-announce-minor-league-field-staffs-for-2018/c-264475472 |title=Red Sox announce Minor League field staffs for 2018 |website=[[MLB.com]] |date=January 2018 |accessdate=July 13, 2018}} ==History== The Red Sox have fielded at least one team in the DSL each season since 1996; the team that season was a cooperative with the [[Houston Astros]]. Since 1997, the Red Sox have fielded their own team. In some seasons, the Red Sox have fielded two teams in the league, "DSL Red Sox 1" and "DSL Red Sox 2". This was the case in 2003, and since 2015, with the exception of 2017.{{cite news |url=http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/red_sox/clubhouse_insider/2017/01/red_sox_drop_one_dominican_summer_league_team |title=Red Sox drop one Dominican Summer League team |first=Evan |last=Drellich |newspaper=[[Boston Herald]] |date= January 11, 2017 |accessdate=July 16, 2018}} In several seasons, the Red Sox have fielded a cooperative team with one or more other MLB clubs; this was the case in 1989 (with the [[Baltimore Orioles]] and [[Milwaukee Brewers]]), 1990 (with the [[Detroit Tigers]] and [[San Diego Padres]]), 1996 (with the Astros), 2000 (with the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]]), and 2001 (with the [[Cleveland Indians]]). The DSL Red Sox reached the league championship series in 2014, and DSL Red Sox 1 won the league championship series in 2016.{{cite web |url=http://sonsofsamhorn.com/baseball/majorleaguebaseball/al-east/boston-red-sox/2016-dsl-red-sox/ |title=The 2016 DSL Red Sox: Taking Pressure Off of Big Papi |first=Brandon |last=Magee |website=sonsofsamhorn.com |date=September 19, 2016 |accessdate=July 16, 2018}} Notable alumni include [[Hanley Ramírez]], who played with the team in 2001,{{cite news |url=https://nesn.com/2014/12/xander-bogaerts-similar-to-young-hanley-ramirez-says-red-sox-coach/2/ |title=Xander Bogaerts Similar To Young Hanley Ramirez, Red Sox Coach Says |first=Ricky |last=Doyle |website=[[New England Sports Network|NESN]] |date=December 2, 2014 |accessdate=July 16, 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://sonsofsamhorn.com/baseball/minor-league/minor-league-reports-minor-league/minor-league-reports/minor-league-report-52915-dominican-summer-league-begins/ |title=Minor League Report 5/29/15 – Dominican Summer League Begins |first=Brandon |last=Magee |website=sonsofsamhorn.com |date=May 29, 2015 |accessdate=July 16, 2018}} [[Xander Bogaerts]], who hit .314 with the team during the 2010 season, and [[Rafael Devers]], who hit .337 with the team during the 2014 season.Baseball-reference.com ==Results by year== ===Cooperative teams=== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox Minister | name = Faisal Karami | image = | imagesize = | office = Minister of Youth and Sports | primeminister = [[Najib Mikati]] | predecessor = Ali Abdullah | successor = Abdul Muttaleb Al Hinawi | term_start = 13 June 2011 | term_end = 15 February 2014 | office2 = | primeminister2= | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|9|26|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Tripoli, Lebanon]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | party = [[Arab Liberation Party]] | residence = | alma_mater = | spouse = | nationality = [[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]] | religion = [[Islam]]<!-- PLEASE DON'T CHANGE THIS TO SHIA OR SUNNI AS THEY ARE SECTS NOT AS A WHOLE RELIGION --> | children = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Faisal Omar Karami''' (born 26 September 1971) is a [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] politician. He served as the minister of youth and sports in [[Lebanese government of June 2011|the cabinet]] of Najib Mikati between 2011 and 2014.<ref name=beirut>{{cite web|title=Faisal Karami|url=http://www.beirut.com/l/17248|publisher=Beirut|accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Karami was born into [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunni]] family in [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]] on 26 September 1971.<ref name=katpro>{{cite web|title=Profile|url=http://www.katagogi.com/Profile/Profile.aspx?l=EN&fid=19546&No=f1066997-2650-46fc-8aab-46a70831260a&nAID=195026&PreveVal=8163|publisher=Katagogi|accessdate=10 March 2013}}</ref> His father is [[Omar Karami]] who was one of the former [[Prime Minister of Lebanon|Prime Ministers]] of [[Lebanon]].<ref name=beirut/><ref name=ala18jan>{{cite news|title=Former PM Karami dismisses attack on his son as "mistake"|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/14694|accessdate=10 March 2013|newspaper=Al Akhbar|date=18 January 2013}}</ref> He is also the nephew of [[Rashid Karami]], who served as prime minister for ten terms, assassinated by Samir Geagea.<ref name=ala18jan/> Faisal Karami studied business administration in [[the United States]].<ref name=now13jun/>
==Career== Karami is the head of [[Arab Liberation Party|the Arab Liberation Party]].<ref name=now13jun>{{cite news|title=Lebanon announces cabinet line-up|url=https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/nownews/lebanon_announces_cabinet_line-up2|accessdate=10 March 2013|work=Now Lebanon|date=13 June 2011}}</ref> He was appointed minister of youth and sports in June 2011 to [[Lebanese government of June 2011|the cabinet]] of [[Najib Mikati]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Mikati forms new Lebanese government|url=http://www.ainalyaqeen.com/arch_2011/June-17/en7.php|accessdate=13 October 2012|work=Ain Alyaqeen|date=17 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=dailystar13611>{{cite news|last=El Basha|first=Thomas|title=Mikati forms 30-member Lebanon Cabinet|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/2011/Jun-13/Lebanon-appoints-new-government.ashx#axzz28P2g9S1z|accessdate=5 October 2012|newspaper=The Daily Star|date=13 June 2011|location=Beirut}}</ref> He was a non-affiliated member and part of [[March 8 Coalition|the March 8 coalition]] in the cabinet.<ref name=lic>{{cite web|title=The New Lebanese Government|url=http://licus.org/liclib/LICRD/LIC%20Cabinet%202011%20Report%20FD.pdf|publisher=Lebanese Information Center|accessdate=13 October 2012|format=Assessment Report|date=July 2011}}</ref> Karami's term ended on 15 February 2014 and Abdul Muttaleb Al Hinawi succeeded him in the post.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lebanese cabinet formed after 10-month stalemate|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/02/15/Fresh-hopes-for-Lebanon-cabinet-formation.html|accessdate=18 February 2014|work=Al Arabiya|date=15 February 2014}}</ref>
===Controversy=== Karami's appointment led to conflict during the cabinet formation process in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Karami and Arslan obstacles are pending|url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArchiveDetails.aspx?ID=281065|accessdate=13 October 2012|newspaper=As Safir|date=June 2011}}</ref> The reason for the conflict was that [[Hezbollah]] had explicitly asked Mikati to assign Faisal Karami as one of the ministers. However, Mikati initially refused this proposal.<ref name=gnews>{{cite news|last=Moubayed|first=Sami|title=Why Najeeb Mikati cannot deliver|url=http://gulfnews.com/opinions/columnists/why-najeeb-mikati-cannot-deliver-1.787478|accessdate=13 October 2012|work=Gulf News|date=5 April 2011}}</ref> Mikati argued that if Karami became minister, three of the five seats would be taken by natives of Tripoli (himself, finance minister [[Mohammad Safadi]], and Karami), leading to imbalance in political representation.<ref name=gnews/> Nevertheless, Karami was appointed as a non-affiliated minister chosen by Hezbollah,<ref name=lic/> and became the seventh [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] member of the cabinet after Lebanese Parliament Speaker [[Nabih Berri]]’s [[Amal Party (Lebanon)|AMAL party]] agreed to give up one of its governmental shares for him.<ref name=naharnet>{{cite news|title=Omar Karami’s Brother: Our Family is Not Honored by Being Represented by Faisal|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/8453|accessdate=13 October 2012|work=Naharnet|date=16 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=mer14jun>{{cite news|title=Mikati unveils 30-member Cabinet dominated by Hizbullah and March 8 allies|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Mikati+unveils+30-member+Cabinet+dominated+by+Hizbullah+and+March+8...-a0260069501|accessdate=10 March 2013|work=The Daily Middle East Reporter|date=14 June 2011}}</ref> Karami's appointment was celebrated in his hometown, Tripoli.<ref name=mfr>{{cite news|title=Incendiary Politics |url=http://www.menafundreview.com/incendiary-politics-2/ |accessdate=13 October 2012 |work=Mena Fund Review |date=4 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202101153/http://www.menafundreview.com/incendiary-politics-2/ |archivedate=2 February 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Attack=== Karami's convoy was attacked in Tripoli on 18 January 2013, injuring four people. Karami escaped the attack unhurt.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lebanon minister escapes convoy attack unhurt|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/01/2013118112454288771.html|accessdate=10 March 2013|work=Al Jazeera|date=18 January 2013}}</ref> Perpetrators were armed radical [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunni]] [[Islamists]].<ref name=aziz24mar>{{cite news|last=Aziz|first=Jean|title=Tripoli: A Cocktail of Fundamentalism|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2013/03/tripoli-cocktail-fundamentalism.html|accessdate=25 March 2013|work=Al Monitor|date=24 March 2013}}</ref> One of the gunmen was wounded and later arrested.<ref name=aziz24mar/>

[[File:Goan_Sports_Association,_Mumbai.jpg|thumb|Goan Sports Association at the city that used to be called [[Bombay]].]]The '''Goan Sports Association''' is the name of a club (later association) and sporting grounds founded in 1929 in [[Mumbai]] (formerly known as [[Bombay]]), India
==Location== It is located at [[Cross Maidan]] at [[Dhobi Talao]] in [[Mumbai]] 400002, behind [[Fashion Street]], in the central and downtown part of the city.
==History== This association, earlier known as a club, had been established in 1929 to promote sports in the bustling megapolis and was the apex body of several sports associations. Football, being a popular sport in the "parent State of [[Goa]]",<ref name="TOI">{{cite web|last1=Sequeira|first1=Rosy|title=HC to hear plea of Goan Sports against eviction|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/HC-to-hear-plea-of-Goan-Sports-against-eviction/articleshow/18881129.cms|website=timesofindia.indiatimes.com|publisher=Times Of India|accessdate=17 August 2016}}</ref> here too the club had been promoting this sport on the ground for the past four-and-half decades. This had meant "thousands of players, schools and colleges in [[Mumbai]] have benefited from using the playground", it was claimed by supporters of this group.
In a petition made before the courts, the supporters of this association said the players trained by the association were participating in various international and national sport events. The lease was extended in 2004 for 30 years up to 2033.<ref name="TOI" />
In 2012, news reports spoke about the upgraded medical facilities there.<ref name=DNA>{{cite web|last1=DNA|first1=Correspondent|title=Goan Sports Association upgrades medical facilities|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report-goan-sports-association-upgrades-medical-facilities-1667858|website=DNAIndia.com}}</ref>
==Home for competition== Goan Sports Association (GSA) grounds has been the venue for a number of football tournaments. For instance, in March 2012, it was the venue for the 15th Goan Sports Association (GSA) veterans’ football tournament for the Late [[Aniceto Fernandes]] Memorial Trophy,<ref name="DNA" /> the Super Division play-off matches,<ref>{{cite web|title=Mumbai Strikers beat state police in super division play-off|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/locality/news-tags/goan-sports-association-ground|website=dnaindia.com|publisher=DNA|accessdate=17 August 2016}}</ref> among others.
Goa Sports Association has its hockey team too, which was in the Third Division in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/tag/goan-sports-association/|website=IndianExpress.com|publisher=Indian Express|accessdate=17 August 2016}} {{deadlink|date=June 2018}}</ref> This hockey team was in the Mumbai first division in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-sports/maidan-magic/article14402177.ece |date=26 June 2016|newspaper=The Hindu|title=maidan magic|accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Goan Sports tops in 17-goal thriller|url=http://www.afternoondc.in/sports/goan-sports-tops-in-17-goal-thriller/article_170661|website=afternoondc.in|publisher=The Afternoon Despatch & Courier}}</ref>
==Court case== In March 2013, however, news reports<ref name="TOI" /> said the [[Bombay High Court]] was to then hear a petition by the Goan Sports Association challenging the termination of its lease from a 1,40,000 square feet plot near Cross Maidan. Judges S J Vazifdar and Justice Mridula Bhatkar were to then hear the association's petition challenging the 21 December 2012 government resolution terminating the lease dead of the plot and directing the deputy director of the Sports and Youth Service, Mumbai division, to take further action for recovery of dues and taking possession of the ground.<ref name="TOI" />

A '''hidden ball trick''' is a play in which a player deceives the opposing team about the location of the ball. In the game of [[baseball]], the defense deceives the runner about the location of the ball, in an effort to [[tag out]] the runner. In [[goal (sports)| ]]-based sports (e.g., [[American football]] and [[lacrosse]]), the offense deceives the defense about the location of the ball, in attempt to get the defense running the wrong way, such as in a [[fumblerooski]]. ==Baseball== In the game of [[baseball]], the defense deceives the runner about the location of the ball, in an effort to [[tag out]] the runner. ===Execution=== A [[fielder (baseball)|fielder]] may employ the hidden ball trick when a runner is on base. Variations of the play exist: they all involve a fielder keeping the baseball without the runner's knowledge, waiting for the runner to [[lead off]] of his [[base (baseball)|base]], and then quickly [[tag (baseball)|tagging]] the runner out. For the trick to work, the fielder (generally an [[infielder]]) must get the ball while the ball is still [[dead ball|in play]], and the runner must not realize that the fielder has the ball. Variations of the play usually involve a fielder miming a throw to the pitcher or another defender while keeping the baseball out of sight, often in his glove. If the runner does not detect the deception and realize that the play is still ongoing, he may stray off the base and be tagged out.{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Malcolm|title=Ozzie, the spud & the Ol' Hidden Ball Trick: Great stories surround baseball's ancient deception play|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/baseball/mlb/story/2013/04/12/sp-mlb-kelly-hidden-ball-trick.html|publisher=CBC Sports|accessdate=May 25, 2013}} A related tactic is to quickly re-tag the runner after an unsuccessful tag in the hope that his hand or foot has lost contact with the base after a [[slide (baseball)|slide]].{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Malcolm|title=Ozzie, the spud & the Ol' Hidden Ball Trick: Great stories surround baseball's ancient deception play|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/baseball/mlb/story/2013/04/12/sp-mlb-kelly-hidden-ball-trick.html|publisher=CBC Sports|accessdate=May 25, 2013}} (describing the move first baseman Dave Bergman used successfully) In most situations, the [[balk]] rule precludes a [[pitcher]] from performing a hidden ball trick. In high school and college baseball, a balk is called (NFHS R6-S2-A5) if a runner or runners are on base and the pitcher, while he is not touching the pitcher's plate, makes any movement naturally associated with his pitch, or he places his feet on or astride the pitcher's plate, or positions himself within approximately five feet of the pitcher's plate without having the ball. In professional baseball, under Rule 8.05(i), a [[balk]] occurs if the pitcher is standing on or astride of the [[pitcher's rubber|pitching rubber]] without the ball. As play after a [[foul ball]], [[hit batsman]], or [[time-out (sport)|time out]], must not resume until the pitcher is on the [[pitcher's mound]], the [[infielder]] cannot use these times to obtain the ball. ===Examples=== {{Example farm|section|date=November 2018}} While variations exist, use of the play in major league baseball is somewhat rare. Some say that the hidden-ball trick has been pulled fewer than 300 times in over 100 years of major league baseball. A [[first baseman]] may attempt the play after a pitcher, in an attempt to [[pick off]] a runner, throws to first. The first baseman then fakes the throw back to the pitcher while keeping the ball in his glove, and if and when the runner leaves the base, tags the runner. [[Dave Bergman]] is a former first baseman who pulled this off on multiple occasions. A second baseman could attempt a similar play after a successful [[steal (baseball)|steal]] of second base, having received a throw from the catcher. Former [[second baseman]] [[Marty Barrett (second baseman)|Marty Barrett]] also successfully performed the trick more than once. After a runner reached second base on a ball hit to the outfield, and after receiving the throw in from the outfield, he faked a throw to the pitcher while retaining the ball. To aid the deception, Barrett took the throw with his back to the runner, then placed the ball between the back of his glove and one of his fingers: this way, he exposed his glove to the runner without the ball in the pocket, suggesting that he did not have the ball. Other players have hidden the ball in their armpit. Former [[third baseman]] [[Matt Williams (third baseman)|Matt Williams]] used a different technique. On more than one occasion, he asked the runner to step off the base so that Williams could sweep the dirt off it, then tagged out the runner when the runner complied.Zumsteg, Derek. [https://books.google.com/books?id=WphEuMXo50oC&pg=PA66 ''The Cheater's Guide to Baseball'']. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2007, pp. 66-67. {{ISBN|978-0-618-55113-2}}. This worked twice.{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Malcolm|title=Ozzie, the spud & the Ol' Hidden Ball Trick: Great stories surround baseball's ancient deception play|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/baseball/mlb/story/2013/04/12/sp-mlb-kelly-hidden-ball-trick.html|publisher=CBC Sports|accessdate=May 25, 2013}} (referencing Zumsteg) Former third baseman [[Mike Lowell]] also made the trick work twice, each time after a throw in from the outfield. The key to Lowell's success was acting, placement, and waiting: acting as if nothing was on, standing away from the bag but not too far from it, and waiting, at least 10 seconds, until the runner on third took a few steps. On June 8, {{Baseball year|2007}}, [[shortstop]] [[Julio Lugo]] of the [[Boston Red Sox]] caught [[Alberto Callaspo]] of the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]]. However, third baseman Lowell, Lugo's teammate, claimed it was not a true hidden ball trick since the pitcher did most of the work "selling" the trick.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/baseball/redsox/articles/2007/06/10/lowell_isnt_hiding_his_feelings_on_trick_play/ |title=Boston Red Sox – Lowell isn't hiding his feelings on trick play – The Boston Globe |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613043628/http://www.boston.com/sports/baseball/redsox/articles/2007/06/10/lowell_isnt_hiding_his_feelings_on_trick_play/ |archivedate=June 13, 2007 }} Before Lugo caught Callaspo, Lowell laid claim to the last successful hidden ball trick and held that position for eight years to the day. Lowell's occurred on August 10, {{Baseball year|2005}}, when he, then with the [[Florida Marlins]], caught the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] [[Luis Terrero]], with reliever [[Todd Jones]] on the mound. Lowell also caught [[Brian Schneider]] of the [[Montreal Expos]] in {{Baseball year|2004}}. Third baseman [[Bill Coughlin]] was reputed to have been the master of the hidden ball trick. Although not verified, Coughlin reportedly pulled it off seven times.{{cite web|url=http://forums.nyyfans.com/archive/index.php/t-87848.html|title=Hidden ball trick [Archive] - NYYFans.com Forum|website=forums.nyyfans.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballthinkfactory.org/files/dialed_in/discussion/august_18_2005/|title=BBTF's Dialed In Discussion :: August 18, 2005|website=www.baseballthinkfactory.org}} The first known recorded and successful example of Coughlin's hidden ball trick was against the [[Detroit Tigers]] on September 24, 1901, as seen from a contemporary description of the game:
In returning the sphere to the infield the ball was thrown to our tricky third baseman and he promptly did a little sleight-o'-hand work, his hands moving faster than [[Coach (baseball)|coachers]]' eyes, and shoved the ball up under his arm and assumed his position as it there were nothing wrong. [[Bill Carrick|Carrick]] was standing in the box as if he were about to toss the globule over, and [[Jack Cronin|Cronin]] eased off the [[Base (baseball)|ottoman]] slightly, but enough to get him caught, and he returned to the bench amids the jeers and howls of the populace.{{Cite news|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87062245/1901-09-25/ed-1/seq-3/|title=The Washington times. (Washington [D.C.]) 1901-1902, September 25, 1901, Image 3|date=1901-09-25|access-date=2018-09-28|pages=3|issn=2151-3325}}
He did it again on September 3, {{Baseball year|1906}}, catching [[George Stone (outfielder)|George Stone]] in the first inning. In Game 2 of the [[1907 World Series]], Coughlin caught [[Jimmy Slagle]] with a hidden ball trick, the only one in World Series history. The play went from [[Germany Schaefer]] to Coughlin.[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=Bill_Coughlin_1877&page=chronology The Ballplayers – Bill Coughlin | BaseballLibrary.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103061227/https://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=Bill_Coughlin_1877&page=chronology |date=2007-11-03 }} [[Willie Kamm]] was considered another master of the trick.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ISwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA49&lpg=PA49&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=-2tZpi_gMU&sig=opO2USN7Fu4SzO-dw5Ks1yj_5sk&hl=en&ei=n51WTLfLOMT58AabrYTgBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CCQQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=''Kamm-ouflage!'', by Edgar Munzel, Baseball Digest, November 1956, Vol. 15, No. 10, ISSN 0005-609X|website=google.com}} On April 30, {{Baseball year|1929}}, in a game against the [[1929 Cleveland Indians season|Cleveland Indians]], Kamm was involved in a rare [[triple play]] involving a hidden-ball trick.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XiwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA63&lpg=PA63&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=Sy5UC929Nr&sig=wEjX2B57FIIkf9zKSYzSsCRAMGw&hl=en&ei=n51WTLfLOMT58AabrYTgBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CBsQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=''The Old Kamm-aflouge'', by Gordon Cobbledick, Baseball Digest, November 1949, Vol. 8, No. 11, ISSN 0005-609X|website=google.com}} The Indians had [[baserunner]]s on first and second bases when [[Carl Lind (baseball)|Carl Lind]] [[Batted ball|grounded out]] to the [[shortstop]]. [[Johnny Hodapp]], who had been on second base, tried to score but got caught in a [[rundown]] between third and home. [[Charlie Jamieson]] advanced to third. Kamm retrieved the ball and [[Tag out|tagged]] both runners, whereupon the umpire ruled Hodapp [[out (baseball)|out]]. Kamm then hid the ball under his arm and waited for Jamieson to step off the base. When he did so, Kamm tagged him out to complete the triple play.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2zADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA14&lpg=PA14&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=V8GLTi5XTv&sig=eKQm4u925C6R-EGEIWC5YWoLVqs&hl=en&ei=OZhWTOelB4K78gb8zsHABA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CCAQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false|title=Baseball Digest, June 2005, Vol. 64, No. 4, ISSN 0005-609X|website=google.com}} On July 12, 2013, [[San Diego Padres]] shortstop [[Everth Cabrera]] attempted to execute the hidden-ball trick on [[San Francisco Giants]] third baseman [[Pablo Sandoval]] after Sandoval hit a double. As pitcher [[Sean O'Sullivan (baseball)|Sean O'Sullivan]] walked onto the mound and Sandoval took his lead, Cabrera, while holding the ball, tagged Sandoval. However, Sandoval had requested and was granted time by second base umpire [[Laz Díaz]] immediately after his double. Because O'Sullivan never assumed his position on the pitcher's plate with the baseball, the umpires appropriately never called "Play" and Cabrera's tag of Sandoval was therefore not legal. The ''Umpire Ejection Fantasy League'' explains this is why a hidden-ball trick may never be executed after a base hit, mound visit, or other event in which "time" is called: in order to put the ball back into play, the pitcher must engage the rubber and if the pitcher engages the rubber without the ball, it is a balk pursuant to Rule 8.05(i)."[http://www.closecallsports.com/2013/07/case-play-2013-07-hidden-ball-trick.html Case Play 2013-07: Hidden Ball Trick Fails due to Time Out]." ''Close Call Sports and the Umpire Ejection Fantasy League''. July 13, 2013. On August 10, 2013, in a Tampa Bay loss to [[2013 Los Angeles Dodgers season|the Los Angeles Dodgers]], 5–0, [[Evan Longoria]], [[2013 Tampa Bay Rays season|Tampa Bay Rays's]] third baseman pulled the trick in the fourth inning on [[Juan Uribe]]. With the bases loaded and no outs, [[A.J. Ellis]] flied out to center field, with [[Andre Ethier]] tagging to score, Uribe tagging to third and [[Skip Schumaker]] tagging to second. Tampa first baseman (and former Dodger) [[James Loney]] cut off center fielder [[Wil Myers|Wil Myers']] throw at the mound, flipped to shortstop [[Yunel Escobar]], who flipped to third baseman Longoria standing several feet behind third base, out of Uribe's line of sight. Longoria just stood behind the bag looking bored and kicking the dirt for several seconds before he got his chance. "I was watching it, and I didn't know what to do to stop it", said pitcher [[Zack Greinke]], who was [[on deck (baseball)|on deck]]. "I didn't want to yell at Uribe, because I might get him off [the bag]. I didn't know what to do. He just lifted his foot for a tenth of a second and Longoria was ready for it. As Uribe shifted his weight and took his foot off the third-base bag, Longoria sneaked from behind and slapped Uribe's thigh with a tag. Longoria looked over his shoulder at umpire [[Ángel Hernández (umpire)|Angel Hernández]], who called Uribe out for an 8-3-6-5 double play. In an after-the-game stunt from his teammates, Uribe was presented with a baseball shoe taped to a base.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814113401/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20130810&content_id=56561040&vkey=news_mlb&c_id=mlb#|title=Rays pull off hidden-ball trick on Dodgers' Uribe {{!}} MLB.com: News|date=2013-08-14|access-date=2018-11-12}} On September 19, 2013, [[2013 Colorado Rockies season|Colorado Rockies]] first baseman [[Todd Helton]] caught [[Matt Carpenter (baseball)|Matt Carpenter]] of the [[2013 St. Louis Cardinals season|St. Louis Cardinals]] for the final out of the first inning in a day game at [[Coors Field]]. Helton, who days earlier had announced his retirement after 17 seasons with the Rockies,{{cite news| url=http://www.denverpost.com/rockies/ci_24098500/todd-helton-retire-after-17-seasons-rockies | work=Denver Post | first=Troy E. | last=Renck | title=Todd Helton to retire after 17 seasons with Colorado Rockies | date=September 14, 2013}} tagged Carpenter after faking a throw back to pitcher [[Roy Oswalt]] following a pickoff attempt. Carpenter was dusting his hands after a head-first slide when he stepped off the back side of first base towards 1B umpire Bill Miller. Cardinals first base coach [[Chris Maloney]] was unable to help Carpenter before Helton got him with a poking tag. "I've been wanting to do that for 17 seasons. Now I can cross that off my bucket list", said the 40-year-old Helton,{{cite news| url=http://www.denverpost.com/rockies/ci_24136544/heltons-hidden-ball-trick-works | work=Denver Post | first=Patrick | last=Saunders | title=Helton's hidden ball trick works | date=September 20, 2013}} who at the time was the oldest active professional athlete in Denver.{{cite news| url=http://www.denverpost.com/broncos/ci_24136591/peyton-manning-plans-attend-final-home-game-buddy | work=Denver Post | first=Mike | last=Klis | title=Peyton Manning plans to attend final home game for buddy Todd Helton | date=September 20, 2013}} The Rockies went on to win 7-6 in a 15 inning game that was the second-longest in Coors Field history.{{cite news| url=http://www.denverpost.com/rockies/ci_24135279/colorado-rockies-win-extra-innings-against-st-louis | work=Denver Post | first=Patrick | last=Saunders | title=Rockies go to 15 innings for dramatic win over the Cardinals | date=September 19, 2013}} In the minor leagues, on August 31, 1987, catcher Dave Bresnahan of the [[Williamsport Bills]] pulled an unusual hidden ball trick against the [[Reading Phillies]] in the [[Eastern League (baseball)|Eastern League]]. With a runner on third base, Bresnahan switched catcher's mitts and put on a glove in which he had secreted a peeled potato. When the pitch came in, Bresnahan fired the white potato down the third-base line, enticing the runner to sprint home. Bresnahan then tagged the runner with the baseball which he kept in his mitt. The umpire awarded the runner home plate for Bresnahan's deception. Bresnahan was banned from the league for the incident, but the fans of the Bills loved the play and the team eventually retired Bresnahan's number.{{cite web | url = http://www.crosscutters.com/history.htm | title = The Great Potato Caper... Revisited | accessdate = 2008-06-21 | author = Tom Speicher | publisher = [[Williamsport Crosscutters]]}}{{cite web | url= http://articles.latimes.com/2012/feb/23/sports/la-sp-sn-sports-urban-legend-potato-20120223 | title= Did a catcher use a potato to pick a runner off third base? |accessdate=2018-06-17| author = Brian Cronin | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''}}{{cite web | url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/tater-toss-010500168--mlb.html | title= Tater toss | date=August 31, 2007| author=Jeff Passan | publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] | accessdate=2018-10-19}} ==Goal-based sports== In [[Goal (sport)|goal]]-based sports (e.g., [[American football]] and [[lacrosse]]), the offense deceives the defense about the location of the ball, in attempt to get the defense running the wrong way. ===American football=== A hidden ball trick is considered a [[trick play]] in [[American football]]. ====Types==== There are various executions of hidden ball plays in American football, including the [[Statue of Liberty play]] and [[Fumblerooski]]. ====Examples==== On November 9, 1895 [[John Heisman]] executed a hidden ball trick utilizing quarterback [[Reynolds Tichenor]] to get [[1895 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]]'s only touchdown in a 6 to 9 loss to [[1895 Vanderbilt Commodores football team|Vanderbilt]]. During the play the ball was snapped to a half-back who was able to slip it under the back of the quarterback's jersey and who in turn was able to trot in for the touchdown. This was also the first game in the south decided by a field goal.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=897&dat=19310124&id=-aNaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zU8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4042,1045626|author=Alan Gould|title=Sport Slants|work=Prescott Evening Courier|date=January 24, 1931}} Heisman later used the trick against [[Glenn Warner|Pop Warner]]'s Georgia team. Warner picked up the trick and later used it at Cornell against Penn State in 1897.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1978030//|title=Ball Under The Jersey|work=Lincoln Evening Journal|page=21|date=December 18, 1930|accessdate=March 13, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} He then used it in [[1903 Carlisle Indians football team|1903]] at [[1903 Carlisle Indians football team|Carlisle]] against Harvard and garnered national attention. The hidden ball trick was famously parodied in the 1930s by the [[Marx Brothers]] in the film ''[[Horse Feathers]]'' and by the [[Three Stooges]] in the comedy short ''[[Three Little Pigskins]]''. ===Other goal-based sports=== Hidden ball tricks can be used in rugby{{Cite web|url=http://www.rugbytoday.com/international/australia-narrowly-defeat-barbarians|title=Australia Narrowly Defeat Barbarians|last=Freeman|first=Allyn|date=2017-10-30|website=www.rugbytoday.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-12}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QAXSBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA73&lpg=PA73&dq=hidden+ball+rugby+-baseball+-football+-lacrosse&source=bl&ots=Dam8vok1zi&sig=GlV9i62tQRH2RSt85r58asH-Dzw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjH4ay2xs_eAhVSDq0KHTfRAo8Q6AEwEnoECAIQAQ#v=onepage&q=hidden%20ball%20rugby%20-baseball%20-football%20-lacrosse&f=false|title=Rugby Classics: Think Rugby: A Guide to Purposeful Team Play|last=Greenwood|first=Jim|date=2015-04-23|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|year=|isbn=9781472918758|location=|pages=73|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AzF99LuXRf4C&pg=PA10&lpg=PA10&dq=hidden+ball+rugby+-baseball+-football+-lacrosse&source=bl&ots=2WqWE2xW_7&sig=iprmTK51L0JRgu4C2itxesyAVfQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjH4ay2xs_eAhVSDq0KHTfRAo8Q6AEwFHoECAAQAQ#v=onepage&q=hidden%20ball%20rugby%20-baseball%20-football%20-lacrosse&f=false|title=Rugby 2nd Edition|last=|first=|publisher=Human Kinetics|year=|isbn=9781450409018|location=|pages=10|language=en}} and lacrosse.{{Cite news|url=https://www.insidelacrosse.com/article/where-does-joel-tinney-s-fake-flip-goal-rank-all-time/48314|title=Where does Joel Tinney's Fake-Flip Goal Rank All-Time?|access-date=2018-11-12}}{{Cite news|url=https://deadspin.com/johns-hopkins-lacrosse-pulled-off-a-flawless-hidden-bal-1792133309|title=Johns Hopkins Lacrosse Pulled Off A Flawless Hidden-Ball Trick|last=Kalaf|first=Samer|work=Deadspin|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/video/clip?id=18641368|title=Lacrosse hidden ball trick keys win - ESPN Video|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en}} ==See also== {{Portal|Sports}} * [[Trick play]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Baseball}} {{American football strategy}} {{no footnotes|date=November 2018}} {{infobox country at games | NOC = HKG | NOCname = [[Sports Federation and Olympic Committee of Hong Kong, China|Sports Federation and Olympic Committee of Hong Kong]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1996 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.hkolympic.org }} {{zh icon}} {{en icon}} | location = [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] | competitors = 23 | sports = 10 | flagbearer = Chan Sau Ying (Opening)
[[Lee Lai Shan]] (Closing) | rank = 49 | gold = 1 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = ? | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Hong Kong]]''' competed at the '''[[1996 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], United States, for the last time as a British colony. At these Games, Hong Kong won its first ever Olympic medal. [[Lee Lai Shan]] won a gold medal in sailing, in the board (mistral) event. ==Medalists== [[File:The 2009 EAG Gallery 09.JPG|thumb|Lee Lai Shan's jacket]] ===Gold=== * [[Lee Lai Shan]] — [[Sailing at the 1996 Summer Olympics|sailing]], women's sailboard (Mistral) ==Results by event== ===[[Swimming at the 1996 Summer Olympics|Swimming]]=== '''Men's 50m Freestyle''' * [[Arthur Li (swimmer)|Arthur Li]] *# Heat – 23.77 (→ did not advance, 42nd place) '''Men's 100m Freestyle''' * [[Arthur Li (swimmer)|Arthur Li]] *# Heat – 51.84 (→ did not advance, 43rd place) '''Men's 400m Freestyle''' * *# Heat – 4:02.68 (→ did not advance, 29th place) '''Men's 200m Butterfly''' * [[Mark Kwok (swimmer)|Mark Kwok]] *# Heat – 2:04.01 (→ did not advance, 34th place) '''Men's 200m Individual Medley''' * [[Mark Kwok (swimmer)|Mark Kwok]] *# Heat – 2:07.61 (→ did not advance, 29th place) '''Men's 400m Individual Medley''' * [[Mark Kwok (swimmer)|Mark Kwok]] *# Heat – 4:31.13 (→ did not advance, 20th place) ==References== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|title=The Official Report of the Centennial Olympic Games, Volume III The Competition Results |author=(ed.) Watkins, Ginger T. |publisher=Peachtree Publishers |location=Atlanta |year=1997 |isbn=1-56145-150-9 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1996/1996v3.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222634/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1996/1996v3.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-09-27 |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-02-13 }} *{{cite web |title=Olympic Medal Winners |publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] |url=http://www.olympic.org/uk/athletes/results/search_r_uk.asp |accessdate=2008-02-13}} {{refend}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080731224357/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/HKG/ Hong Kong] {{NOCin1996SummerOlympics}} [[Category:Nations at the 1996 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Hong Kong at the Summer Olympics by year|1996]] [[Category:1996 in Hong Kong sport|Olympics]] {{HongKong-sport-stub}} {{1996-Olympic-stub}}

{{Infobox gymnast |name= Ioanna Tantcheva |gender= w |image= |image_size= |caption= |fullname= |altname= |nickname= |country= {{flagu|Bulgaria}} |regions= |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1989|3|18|df=y}} |birth_place= |hometown= |residence= |death_date= |death_place= |height= |discipline= RG |level= Senior International Elite |natlteam= 2007-2008 (?) |club= |gym= |collegeteam= |headcoach= |assistcoach= |formercoach= |choreographer= |music= |eponymousskills= |retired= |worldranking= |updated= |show-medals= yes |medaltemplates= <!-- see [[Template:MedalRelatedTemplates]] --> }} '''Ioanna Tantcheva''' ({{lang-bg|Йоанна Танчева}}) (born {{birth date|1989|3|18|df=yes}}) is a [[Bulgaria]]n group [[rhythmic gymnast]]. She represents her nation at international competitions.
She participated at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in Beijing. She also competed at world championships, including at the [[2007 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships]].<ref>{{cite web|title=2007 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships athletes - Ioanna Tantcheva|url=http://gym.longinestiming.com/File/000006030100FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF01|publisher=Longinestiming.com|date= |accessdate=27 January 2016}}</ref>

[[Ames, Iowa]] 50010 | coordinates = {{coord|42|0|51|N|93|38|9|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = October 26, 1973 | opened = September 20, 1975 | expanded = 1976, 1997, 2007, 2015 | renovated = 1997, 2007, 2015 | closed = | demolished = | surface = [[Grass]] (1996–present)
